data.title: Favre: Summer is filled with the sounds of the Hollywood Bowl
data.meta_description: The nearly 18,000-seat outdoor venue officially opens its season Friday. As he was for 16 seasons, Maestro John Mauceri will be on hand â only this time as a special guest and not as the wildly popular conductor of the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra. Having left the position after 2006, he returns as one of two inductees, along with Placido Domingo, into the Bowl's Hall of Fame.
data.text:
By Jeff Favre

The following are highlights from the upcoming season at the bowl. For tickets, visit http://www.ticketmaster.com or call 583-8700.

June 22: 8:30 p.m., opening night, with Placido Domingo and John Mauceri.

June 23: 6 p.m., 18th annual Mariachi USA Festival.

June 30: 6 p.m., Sing-along "Sound of Music."

July 2-4: 7:30 p.m., July 4th Fireworks Spectacular, featuring Riders in the Sky.

July 7: 7:30 p.m., The Decemberists with the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

July 8: 7:30 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Mozart's "The Magic Flute."

July 10: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Shaham's Tchaikovsky Fireworks.

July 11: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: Queen Latifah.

July 12: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Haefliger Plays Ravel.

July 13-14: 8:30 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: John Williams — Maestro of the Movies.

July 15: 7 p.m., KCRW's World Festival: Cafe Tacuba, Groove Armada.

July 17: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Classics Under the Stars.

July 18: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: 50 Years of Stax — Isaac Hayes.

July 19: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Beethoven & Brahms.

July 20-21: 8:30 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Cool Britannia! with Jamie Cullum.

July 22: 7:30 p.m., Hollywood Bowl Orchestra: Savion Glover — On Tap.

July 23: 7:30 p.m., Rush.

July 24: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Sultry Spanish Nights.

July 25: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: Jazz at the Movies — Christian McBride.

July 26: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Chang Plays Bruch.

July 27-28: 8:30 p.m., Viva Las Vegas: An Evening with Gladys Knight with Fireworks.

July 29: 7 p.m., KCRW's World Festival: Spirit of Armenia!

July 31: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Beethoven's Ninth.

Aug. 2: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Bernstein, Copland, Gershwin.

Aug. 3-5: 8:30 p.m., "South Pacific" with Reba McEntire and Brian Stokes Mitchell.

Aug. 7: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: The Grand Tour — London.

Aug. 8: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: Benny Carter's 100 Years of Music.

Aug. 9: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: The Grand Tour — Venice.

Aug. 10-11: 8:30 p.m., Sgt. Pepper's at 40 a Beatles Celebration; Cheap Trick.

Aug. 12: 7 p.m., KCRW's World Festival: Reggae Night VI — Burning Spear, Sly & Robbie.

Aug. 14: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: The Grand Tour — Paris.

Aug. 15: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: Guitar Night — Lee Ritenour, John Scofield.

Aug. 16: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: The Grand Tour — Mozart in Vienna.

Aug. 17-18: 8:30 p.m., From This Moment On: An Evening with Diana Krall.

Aug. 19: 6 p.m., JVC Jazz: Dave Koz, Earl Klugh, Jim Brickman & Michael Lington.

Aug. 21: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Dvorak and Prokofiev.

Aug. 22: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: Bruce Hornsby Trio, Dave Brubeck, Madeleine Peyroux.

Aug. 23: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: French Masters.

Aug. 24-25: 8:30 p.m., Jump, Jive and Swing! with Big Bad Voodoo Daddy with Fireworks.

Aug. 26: 7 p.m., KCRW's World Festival: Macy Gray, Zap Mama.

Aug. 28 and 30: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: The Russians Are Coming.

Aug. 29: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: Nancy Wilson 70th Birthday Celebration, Ramsey Lewis.

Aug. 31 and Sept. 1: 8:30 p.m., The Tchaikovsky Spectacular with Fireworks.

Sept. 2: 7:30 p.m., The Big Picture: The Films of Paramount Pictures.

Sept. 4: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Diavolo Dances Salonen.

Sept. 5: 8 p.m., Jazz at the Bowl: B.B. King, Robert Randolph, James Hunter.

Sept. 6: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: Boris at the Bowl.

Sept. 7-8: 8:30 p.m., Daryl Hall & John Oates.

Sept. 9: 7 p.m., KCRW's World Festival: Underworld.

Sept. 11: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: American Originals.

Sept. 13: 8 p.m., Los Angeles Philharmonic: From the Old World to the New.

Sept. 14-16: 8:30 p.m., Fireworks Finale: Pink Martini at the Cocoanut Grove.

Sept. 23: 7 p.m., Rufus Wainwright Plays Judy Garland: Live at the Hollywood Bowl.

Sept. 27: 7:30 p.m., Pet Shop Boys.

Sept. 29: 7 p.m., Bright Eyes.

Sept. 30: 6:30 p.m., Big Top Bowl: A Global Circus Celebration.

Oct. 1-2: 7 p.m., Dave Matthews Band.

Oct. 12-13: 8 p.m., Genesis.

The Hollywood Bowl is on a roll.

In 2004, with its new, long overdue band shell, which greatly improved acoustics, and two large projection screens to give those in the seats up high a better view, the Bowl broke attendance records.

That record stood until 2005, and the bar was set even higher last season.

"It presents a fun challenge for us to do our jobs even better this year," said Arvind Manocha, general manager of the Bowl. "And I think we've done it."

The nearly 18,000-seat outdoor venue officially opens its season Friday. As he was for 16 seasons, Maestro John Mauceri will be on hand — only this time as a special guest and not as the wildly popular conductor of the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra. Having left the position after 2006, he returns as one of two inductees, along with Placido Domingo, into the Bowl's Hall of Fame.

"There couldn't be a Hall of Fame without John Mauceri," Manocha said. "It's still a strange feeling that he's not here anymore."

The star-packed evening will feature guest performances by Jack Black, Jason Alexander and Kristin Chenoweth. Kirk Douglas and Joe Mantegna will be presenters.

Fireworks have long blasted the Bowl into its summer of music and dance, and this year is no exception. From July 2-4, the Fireworks Spectacular will honor the American West with country band Riders in the Sky. Two of the most famous cowboys, Gene Autry and John Wayne, will be remembered on their 100th anniversaries.

The Bowl offers several annual series as well as new offerings. Rarely, however, is an event repeated exactly the same each year.

"One of those rare examples is Sing-along Sound of Music,'" Manocha said. "People love it, so it makes sense to keep bringing it back."

Hosted by actress and comedian Melissa Peterman ("Reba") on June 30, the evening will begin with a parade of audience members dressed as their favorite characters — or objects — from the 1965 movie musical starring Julie Andrews. Then comes the movie, for which the stars on screen are accompanied by a chorus that's several thousand strong.

Another frequent visitor to the band shell is legendary movie composer John Williams, and he'll be back July 13-14 to conduct the orchestra through some of his more memorable scores, which have garnered him more than 40 Oscar nominations.

A newcomer for 2007 is Oregon indie pop band The Decemberists, which will make its debut with the Los Angeles Philharmonic on July 7.

A two-day concert that particularly excites Manocha is "Sgt. Pepper's at 40 a Beatles Celebration," Aug. 10-11, when conductor Edwin Outwater will lead the orchestra through the most famous album by one of pop music's most famous bands.

Accompanying the orchestra will be special "house band" Cheap Trick as well as Aimee Mann and Joan Osborne.

"When I first thought about this idea I had wanted to involve Cheap Trick," Manocha said. "I am a big fan. "Beatles producer George Martin produced an early Cheap Trick album for which he re-created the end of the song A Day in the Life.' I knew they would be able to do the material justice."

Though musicals and operas were first performed at the Bowl more than 70 years ago, it wasn't until the past decade that such shows have become an annual tradition. For the first time last year the event was expanded to three nights, and this year's offering of "South Pacific" will also run a long weekend, Aug. 3-5. Reba McEntire and Brian Stokes Mitchell, with musical director Paul Gemignanni, will again tackle the Rodgers and Hammerstein classic that they performed two years ago at Carnegie Hall.

"We've been talking about it for some time, and finally the stars literally aligned," Manocha said.

Classical music with the Los Angeles Philharmonic reigns at the Bowl on most Tuesdays and Thursdays, with Leonard Slatkin and others taking on guest conductor duties. A few of the guest artists this year are pianists Andreas Haefliger, July 12, and Christopher O'Riley, July 17; violinists Sarah Chang, July 26, and Martin Chalifour, Aug. 9; and the Los Angeles Master Chorale, July 31.

Highlights of the Jazz at the Bowl series include Queen Latifah, July 11; Isaac Hayes, Booker T. Jones and other artists from soul label Stax Records, July 18; and "Jazz at the Movies," July 25, in which a big band and strings will play tunes by Duke Ellington, Count Basie and more as clips of classic movies are shown in the background.

Although the Bowl solicits top classical, jazz and pop talents, it also has helped promote lesser-known acts.

Pink Martini, the 14-member Latin-laced jazz ensemble, has graduated from the bottom of a world music bill at the Bowl to a headliner for its trio of closing night concerts, "Fireworks Finale," Sept. 14-16.

The concerts will re-create the spirit of the Cocoanut Grove at the recently demolished Los Angeles landmark Ambassador Hotel. Carol Channing and Merv Griffin will be special guests.

— E-mail freelance columnist Jeff Favre at jjfavre@yahoo.com.
